hypotheses: H*: Among low-caste households, residing in villages dominated by lower castes is associated with greater agricultural income compared to residing in villages dominated by upper castes.
claim.statement: agricultural yields are systematically higher for low-caste households residing in villages dominated by lower castes (BACs), in terms of total land ownership, compared to villages dominated by upper castes.

data.source: Primary data collected in 1997–1998 by researchers from the World Bank and India.
data.notes: Data is from villages in south and southeastern Uttar Pradesh and north and central Bihar. Excludes Muslim dominated villages (10% of sample) and Muslim households (2% in Hindu dominated villages).

method.description: The study exploits dramatic village-level variation in caste composition and land ownership to identify the effects of village-level caste differentiation on household-level outcomes.
steps: Collect household and village level data from Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.
Identify villages dominated by upper castes and lower castes (BACs).
Compare agricultural outcomes for lower caste households across these village types.
Control for various factors using regression models to capture the impact of caste dominance on income.
method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) estimation and Instrumental Variables (IV) approach.
method.independent_variables: Caste dominance in the village, household literacy, land ownership.
method.control_variables: Education, land ownership, caste identity, district and state fixed effects.

results.summary: Low-caste households have significantly higher agricultural income and yields in villages where the land is primarily owned by low castes (BACs) due to better access to private groundwater markets.

numerical_results.value: 45% higher for low-caste households in low-caste dominated villages

metadata.original_paper_title: Caste as an Impediment to Trade
